messages: 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:02): hixie, from the IRC logs I see you wrote "anyone have any web pages that use mathml that aren't, like, the blogs of editors of the spec or anything like that?" to which I'd suggest the only web pages that make *good* use HTML are from a similar segment of the population
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:08): "You can learn a lot by viewing an interesting page with MathML and selecting 'View Page Source'." from http://www.pdas.com/mathml.htm suggests it exists
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:10): finds one page using a <math> element
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:11): http://www.unics.uni-hannover.de/cpr/x/rueckemann/de/rueckemann.html - "Paderborn Center for Parallel Computing (PC<MATH CLASS=INLINE><SUP>2</SUP></MATH>)"

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:11): http://www-math.mit.edu/18.013A/MathML/chapter06/section01.xhtml is from http://www-math.mit.edu/18.013A/ which is a MIT course material...since MIT is part of W3C maybe that doesn't count?
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:12): http://www.math.uah.edu/stat/ seems to use it throughout (states MathML support as a requirement on the homepage)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:12): btw I'm finding these by Googling for "mathml on the web"
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:13): http://www.math.uah.edu/stat/foundations/Sets.xhtml - an example from the previous site
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:22): http://www.mozilla.org/projects/mathml/ was a project to develop MathML authoring tools and interoperable practices, such as using <object>

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:26): http://pear.math.pitt.edu/mathzilla/Examples/markupOftheWeek.mhtml uses MathML, the site also has this paper where MathML is used inside sentences: http://pear.math.pitt.edu/mathzilla/Examples/DynHieruni.xml

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:37): http://www1.chapman.edu/~jipsen/mathml/asciimath.html uses ASCII which is then turned into markup using JS, it states "ASCIIMathML is being used with Movable Type, WordPress, phpBB, and many wikis." but I can't find links to example sites
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:38): the Web appears to be a big place

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (03:53): http://www.dessci.com/en/products/webeq/ is a MathML editor which produces MathML and uses Java. that page claims "The world's leading e-learning companies, content developers and education portals are using WebEQ to create web-based learning environments that help educators engage students in math and science on the web." but I cannot find example pages of these
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:05): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: Probably a lot on intranets, but that doesn't help us
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:10): 0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8: html5 has <ol reversed> or some such now
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (04:10): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:10): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: oh i'm not looking for pages that use mathml correctly :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:11): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: i'm looking for "real" pages
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (04:14): http://golem.ph.utexas.edu/category/ and the journals mentioned in the mathml thread seem relevant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:32): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9, webben: thanks for the links
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:47): hixie, np. there were lots of results for searches along those lines
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:47): cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:47): i shall investigate further
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:51): webben, <ol reversed> was in 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e's response here http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2008Feb/0357.html
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:51): (search for "9 Jan 2008" to see messages which led to it)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:52): (the forum thread it links to here http://forums.whatwg.org/viewtopic.php?t=130 has lots of use cases)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:52): it's in the spec here: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#reversed
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:53): and in the multipage version (which I much prefer!) here: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/section-grouping.html#reversed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:55): i hate multipage specs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:55): i can never find anything in them
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:57): as an author, I'm usually looking for a specific element or attribute, so they are OK if there's an index of those things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:58): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:58): we will eventually add much better indexing
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (04:58): the front page is pretty good with find-in-page
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:59): (gsnedders doesn't know it yet, but if he ends up writing a good preprocessor, he'll probably end up helping out a lot in that area)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:01): it's weird how people associate syntax with language
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:01): (c.f. David Carlisle's e-mail)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:03): there are so many I don't know which that is :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:03): more recent ones
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:03): it is weird that we are getting so much reluctance from the mathml group to make their syntax easier
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:03): given that the mathml syntax is the number 1 problem with mathml
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:04): oh, I see
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:06): if the people using the syntax are happy with the syntax then it doesn't seem like a problem to me...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:07): the people who aren't happy with their syntax aren't using it :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:08): seriously though, compare the first two examples in http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Equations_in_HTML
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:08): how do we _not_ want people to use the second?
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:08): neither are things I'd ever want to write, personally :P
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:09): from what I've read, the tools handle the syntax and the author uses a word processor, or they use an ASCII-based syntax which is then coverted by a tool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:09): can't argue with that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:09): unfortunately "the tools with save us" has rarely worked on the web
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:10): indeed, but mathematicians aren't noobs and the MathML which exists seems pretty well authored, from the little I've seen
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:11): just like english majors aren't the only audience of prose html elements, mathematicians aren't the only audience for the math parts
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:11): and frankly, most mathematicians _are_ noobs when it comes to writing markup and using equation editors
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:11): after all, they're experts in maths, not editors
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:12): you think non-mathematicians would use any sort of math markup?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:18): i'm not a mathematician
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:18): and my final year report for my physics degree had loads of mathml in it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:18): handwritten
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:18): painfully
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:19): my idea of a "mathematician" is broad and would include people who publish any degree-level maths
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:20): would you expect math markup to appear around casual sums, like people adding up the cost-per-year of their TV service?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:21): no
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:21): but i wouldn't be surprised to see it in a web page talking about 3d graphics
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:21): ok, so we only expect math markup from people who are fairly serious about maths?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:22): i'm not sure what "fairly serious" means really
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:22): i'd expect people to use things like fractions long before they knew about integration

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:24): well a brief adhoc survey of pages that use mathml suggests that none of them use both presentational mathml and content mathml, though one page did use content mathml and convert it to presentational mathml using xslt, which is pretty cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:24): clearly i need to do a more serious study

0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (05:36): "A valid browsing context name is any string that does not start with a U+005F LOW LINE character, or, a string that case-insensitively matches one of: _self, _parent, or _top. (Names starting with an underscore are reserved for special keywords.)" ... is making "_blank" invalid deliberate?
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (05:36): http://www.w3.org/html/wg/html5/#valid8
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:40): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:40): but we'll probably change that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (05:41): and instead make it optional for UAs to honour it
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (05:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Okay, just wondering. Thanks for the info. :)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:51): the month I took off work ends on 1st April, officially. so making websites will become my priority once again
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (05:51): night night
